(Photo: Martin E. Klimek, USA TODAY)

SAN FRANCISCO -- Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is expected to publicly speak out about the social network's response to the misuse of tens of millions of Facebook users' private information.

Zuckerberg's response would be his first since details emerged of improper use of Facebook user data by Cambridge Analytica, a political consultancy with ties to President Donald Trump's 2016 campaign.

(March 20) AP

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg speaks to guests gathered for a 'birthday' celebration at Facebook headquarters in Menlo Park, California on Tuesday, January, 31, 2017.
Cambridge Analytica, which had said all data obtained through Facebook was done "legally and fairly," revealed Tuesday it suspended CEO Alexander Nix pending a full investigation.
A person familiar with Zuckerberg’s thinking said the Facebook CEO plans to speak within the next 24 hours about the situation, which has unfolded in a crescendo in recent days.
The Federal Trade Commission is probing Facebook over the matter, and the social network faces investigations from attorneys general in both New York and Massachusetts.
CLOSE Facebook’s latest privacy scandal involves Trump campaign consultants who allegedly stole data on millions of users in order to influence elections.
Shares have fallen more than 10% this week, including a 7% drop on Monday, the stock's worst drop in four years, according to FactSet.
Since the revelations, lawmakers in the U.S., the U.K. and Europe have contacted Facebook seeking answers about the situation.
Facebook CEO Zuckerberg lost almost $5 billion as the company's market cap fell more than $36 billion to $501.3 billion.
It has also again drawn scrutiny over whether Facebook can protect users' personal information from third parties.
Facebook met with lawmakers Tuesday and planned to meet again Wednesday to discuss the case.
